Aeronautical Exhibit
A complete exhibit of the latest
aeronautical instruments will be
shown by courtesy of the Frieze Company. A unit air conditioner and an
.cu.omatic controller for regulating
temperature will be shown. In relation to this last field, The Baltimore
and Ohio Railroad is showing how
railroad cars are air-conditioned.
In connection with the exhibit of
another material, transite, a mixture
of asbestos, porcelain, and cement,
Professor Christie told how its use had
solved a serious problem at Hopkins
several years ago. In Remsen Hall,
the conventional iron and steel piping
was of no value, for the acids used
in the laboratories dissolved it. A
new material had to be used. Transite
was tried, and met the test successfully.
In addition to the exhibits supplied by various industries, the Mechanical Engin)sering exhibits will
also include demonstrations of their
own equipment and of the work
done in their own laboratories.

"News-Letter" Staff
Awaits Decision Of S.A.C.
Due to alleged violations of
S.A.C. rules, the NEWS - LETTER
results are being held up.
The S.A.C., composed of W. Holt
Maulsby, chairman; William Erlanger, and John Royster, are
considering this matter. Their decision will be rendered shortly and
the NEWS-LETTER staff will act
upon it.
The Editorial Board, if necessary, will meet again for recommendation of the nominees.
In the event of a new election
the entire staff will be informed.

New Lecture Course
production To Be Given
Thursday

The first meeting of the course on
Raman Reproduction given by Dr.
klan F. Guttmacher, Associate in
Obstetrics at the Johns Hopkins Medical School, will be held in room 112,
Gilman Hall, Thursday at four o'clock.
The course, which will meet weekly,
is being sponsored by the Hopkins
chapter of the American Student
I %lion.
Beginning with a discussion of the
various patterns of sexual behavior
Submarnmalian and Mammalian
'groups, the course will develop into
a discussion of the various aspects of
talinan reproduction. Dr. Guttmacher
has asked that the meetings be very
informal, and questions will be welcorne at all times.

Professor Gregory, who is listed
among the speakers at the technical
sessions, died suddenly on January
18. However, he had completed the
paper the day before his death, and
it will be read by one of his associates.

National Park Seminary
National Park Seminary, in Silver
'Springs, Maryland, will be the scene
of the next concert on Saturday, February 27. The Club will journey to
Atlantic City for its annual concert
on Saturday, March 6. Catonsville
High School will hear the closing presentation on Friday, March 12.
Other officers of the Club are John
J. Ghinger and Allan L. Pinkerton,
vice-presidents; Thomas E. Ellis and
Bradford Johnson, junior business
managers; and Stanley Finkel, publicity manager.
Osmar P. Steinwald is director of
the Glee Club, and Conrad Gebelein,
mentor of the Banjo Club and Hawaiian Trosipe.

Harvard

Born In Bucharest
Dr. Gruenbaum was born in Bucharest in January 15, 1885, and came
to the United States after studying
at the University of 13ucharest. He
received his Ph.D. at Hopkins in 1911,
becoming an instructor in Romance
Languages that same year. He was
one of the editors of Modern Language Notes, the oldest periodical
in the world devoted to modern literature. Dr. Gruenbaum was also
preparing three manuscripts for publication in the near future.
Professor Gregory was a native of
Cambridge, Mass., and received his
education at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. After graduating from M.I.T., he worked for sanitary organizations in Boston, Albany, Philadelphia, Jersey City, Columbus, and Newark, finally setting
up his own offices in New York.
Head Of Civil Engineering
He came to Baltimore In 1919, becoming a member of the faculty of
the J.H.U. the following year. When
he died he was the head of the Civil
Engineering Department. At the same
time that he held this position he also
held several important positions in
this state as consultin,g engineer. He
held three outstanding awards--the
Thomas Fitch Rowland prize, won in
1910, the James Laurie prize, awarded
in 1930, and the Rudolph Hering
medal in 1935.

be

Professor
Dr. J. W. Johnson OffersSpecialCourse
To Lecture Here Botany Department Sponsors
Supper Club To Hear Fisk
Professor Lecture On
February 16

Dr. James Weldon Johnson, Professor of Creative Literature, Fisk University, will be the Supper Club
Speaker and University Lecturer
February 16.
Before going into academic work,
Dr. Johnson was a member of the
Florida Bar and Secretary of the
National Association for the Advancement of Colored People. He
also served as United States Consul
to Puerto Cabello, Venezuela in 1906;
and as Consul to Corinto, Nicaragua,
from 1909-1919.
He is a graduate of Atlanta University, and received further degrees
at Columbia, Talladega College, and
Howard University. He practiced law
at Jacksonville. and moved to New
York in 1901.
At this time he collaborated with
his brother in writing for the light
opera stage, and produced the English
version of the libretto to the grand
opera "Goyescas", which was produced in the Metropolitan Opera
House in 1915.
He is a director of the American
Fund for Public Service, and a Trustee of Atlanta University.
Among his writings are included
The Autobiography of An Ex-Colored Man, Fifty Years and, Other
Poems, Self
Determining
Haiti,
The Book of American Negro Poetry,
Along This Way,(his autobiography.)
He is a frequent contributor to The
Century, Harper's, and The American Magazine.

Course In Phycomycetes
Given By Dr. Western
Dr. William H. Western, Jr., Professor of Cryptogamic Botany, at Harvard University, will give a special
lecture and laboratory course in the
field of the lower fungi, phycomycetes. The course, which began yesterday, is being held under the sponsorship of the Botany department,
and will meet daily until March 20.
A graduate of Dartmouth College
in 1911, Dr. Western received his
Ph.D. degree in 1915 from Harvard
University. Since 1921, he has been
teaching at Harvard University. Previous to that time, he was with the
United States Department of Agriculture, serving as Pathologist, and cereral investigator for the Bureau of
Plant Industry. In 1920 his work carried him to the Phillipine Islands.
Since he has been at Harvard, Dr.
Western has become recognized as
one of the leaders in his particular
field of botanical research.

'Stormer's To Hold Elections
The Barnstormers Club, Dramatic
group of tile Hopkins, will hold its annual elections this Friday at 4 o'clock
at a meeting for members only.
Anyone is eligible for membership
who has served on any of the staffs
which comprise the Barnstormers
Club, the acting, production, and business staffs.
In exceptional cases
only are those elected who have served
but one year.

CATHERINE DE MEDICI AND
THE LOST REVOLUTION, by
Ralph Roeder. The Viking Press,
1937. $3.75. 629 pp.
For four years, siace he completed
The Man of the Renaissance, Ralph
Roeder has been at work on another
great biography, another historical
panorama of a troubled and colorful
world. The Medici family is perfect
material for biography, none of them
more so than Catherine, and her puzzling character has been a favorite
problem for biographers. It seems
unlikely, however, that anyone in our
day will write the story of Catherine
with such thoughtful penetration,such
dramatic intensity, or with such a
clear appreciation of the tangled and
international
bitter
background
against which she lived her life.
Catherine de'Medici was raised as
a symbol, married for political expediency into the most brilliant house
in Europe, and honored only for the
children whom, after ten years of
sterility, she bore to Henri II. In all,
she bore him ten, three of them to
become kings of France, and in the
years of her fertility she lived within
her family, removed from the political turmoil of the Renaissance struggle for power. Then, at the age of
forty, she put aside her distaff and set
out to become the ruler of France.

of true motives, his knowledge of the

The many desirable constructional features of
the modern high-speed electric locomotive will
be incorporated in the design as a result of
General Electric's many years of experience in
building and equipping electric locomotives.

1.11111111
,

BY A NOSE
A century ago there was a race between a horse
and a locomotive. No such race will be necessary to determine the supremacy of the steam.
electric locomotive being built for the Union
Pacific Railroad by the General Electric Company. This new unit will get its first trial run
on the test tracks at the Erie, Pa. Works early
this year.
This new passenger unit will carry a steamturbine electric generating plant to feed power
to the traction motors. The turbine will exhaust through condensers, using the same water over and over with small additions to make
up for leakage. A new, highly efficient type of
steam boiler has been built, and heavy fuel
oil similar to that used in present-day locomotives will be used.
The new unit will be a double-cab locomotive,
streamlined, practically smokeless, and provided with power equipment for air-comb tioning the trailing passenger cars. It is rated at
5000 horsepower and is capable of hauling
1000-ton trains at a speed of 110 miles an hour.
The efficient fuel consumption will allow runs of
hundreds of miles at top speed without a stop.

LOSE A NEEDLE?
Not a needle in a haystack, but perhaps a needle
in a rug. During the manufacture of rugs,
needles may become broken and embedded in
the finished product. Former methods of inspection were tedious and time-wasting, but a
new magnetic device indicates the exact location of the steel fragment.
This iron detector, developed in the General
Engineering Laboratory of the General Electric
Company, consists of a test coil, a motor-generator set, and an amplifier. The rug is passed
through the magnetic field twice in directions
at right angles. The presence of a broken
needle causes a distortion in the magnetic field
and consequently an unbalanced voltage in the
secondary coil. This unbalance is amplified,
and the relays cause signal lights to glow.
Detectors of similar principle have previously
been developed for such uses as detecting scrap
iron in sugar cane and in scrap cellophane. The
General Engineering Laboratory is constantly
receiving problems from industrial concerns
and is developing equipment or giving suggestions to solve these problems.

Jay Yee Quintet Drills
For Contest With Loyola
The members of the Jay Vee basketball squad will start drills this
week in preparation for a clash with
the Loyola Jay Vee group at Evergreen Saturday night. The contest
will be scheduled to take place before the varsity game.
In their rather short program this
campaign, the yearlings have done
very well. Except for a defeat in the
last minutes of play by Western
Maryland, the Jays have won all their
games. In two seasons of play they
have succumbed only once.

Aeronautical Exhibit
A complete exhibit of the latest
aeronautical instruments will be
shown by courtesy of the Frieze Company. A unit air conditioner and an
.cu.omatic controller for regulating
temperature will be shown. In relation to this last field, The Baltimore
and Ohio Railroad is showing how
railroad cars are air-conditioned.
In connection with the exhibit of
another material, transite, a mixture
of asbestos, porcelain, and cement,
Professor Christie told how its use had
solved a serious problem at Hopkins
several years ago. In Remsen Hall,
the conventional iron and steel piping
was of no value, for the acids used
in the laboratories dissolved it. A
new material had to be used. Transite
was tried, and met the test successfully.
In addition to the exhibits supplied by various industries, the Mechanical Engin)sering exhibits will
also include demonstrations of their
own equipment and of the work
done in their own laboratories.

"News-Letter" Staff
Awaits Decision Of S.A.C.
Due to alleged violations of
S.A.C. rules, the NEWS - LETTER
results are being held up.
The S.A.C., composed of W. Holt
Maulsby, chairman; William Erlanger, and John Royster, are
considering this matter. Their decision will be rendered shortly and
the NEWS-LETTER staff will act
upon it.
The Editorial Board, if necessary, will meet again for recommendation of the nominees.
In the event of a new election
the entire staff will be informed.

Born In Bucharest
Dr. Gruenbaum was born in Bucharest in January 15, 1885, and came
to the United States after studying
at the University of 13ucharest. He
received his Ph.D. at Hopkins in 1911,
becoming an instructor in Romance
Languages that same year. He was
one of the editors of Modern Language Notes, the oldest periodical
in the world devoted to modern literature. Dr. Gruenbaum was also
preparing three manuscripts for publication in the near future.
Professor Gregory was a native of
Cambridge, Mass., and received his
education at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. After graduating from M.I.T., he worked for sanitary organizations in Boston, Albany, Philadelphia, Jersey City, Columbus, and Newark, finally setting
up his own offices in New York.
Head Of Civil Engineering
He came to Baltimore In 1919, becoming a member of the faculty of
the J.H.U. the following year. When
he died he was the head of the Civil
Engineering Department. At the same
time that he held this position he also
held several important positions in
this state as consultin,g engineer. He
held three outstanding awards--the
Thomas Fitch Rowland prize, won in
1910, the James Laurie prize, awarded
in 1930, and the Rudolph Hering
medal in 1935.

Professor
Dr. J. W. Johnson OffersSpecialCourse
To Lecture Here Botany Department Sponsors
Supper Club To Hear Fisk
Professor Lecture On
February 16

Dr. James Weldon Johnson, Professor of Creative Literature, Fisk University, will be the Supper Club
Speaker and University Lecturer
February 16.
Before going into academic work,
Dr. Johnson was a member of the
Florida Bar and Secretary of the
National Association for the Advancement of Colored People. He
also served as United States Consul
to Puerto Cabello, Venezuela in 1906;
and as Consul to Corinto, Nicaragua,
from 1909-1919.
He is a graduate of Atlanta University, and received further degrees
at Columbia, Talladega College, and
Howard University. He practiced law
at Jacksonville. and moved to New
York in 1901.
At this time he collaborated with
his brother in writing for the light
opera stage, and produced the English
version of the libretto to the grand
opera "Goyescas", which was produced in the Metropolitan Opera
House in 1915.
He is a director of the American

Course In Phycomycetes
Given By Dr. Western
Dr. William H. Western, Jr., Professor of Cryptogamic Botany, at Harvard University, will give a special
lecture and laboratory course in the
field of the lower fungi, phycomycetes. The course, which began yesterday, is being held under the sponsorship of the Botany department,
and will meet daily until March 20.
A graduate of Dartmouth College
in 1911, Dr. Western received his
Ph.D. degree in 1915 from Harvard
University. Since 1921, he has been
teaching at Harvard University. Previous to that time, he was with the
United States Department of Agriculture, serving as Pathologist, and cereral investigator for the Bureau of
Plant Industry. In 1920 his work carried him to the Phillipine Islands.
Since he has been at Harvard, Dr.
Western has become recognized as
one of the leaders in his particular
field of botanical research.

CATHERINE DE MEDICI AND
THE LOST REVOLUTION, by
Ralph Roeder. The Viking Press,
1937. $3.75. 629 pp.
For four years, siace he completed
The Man of the Renaissance, Ralph
Roeder has been at work on another
great biography, another historical
panorama of a troubled and colorful
world. The Medici family is perfect
material for biography, none of them
more so than Catherine, and her puzzling character has been a favorite
problem for biographers. It seems
unlikely, however, that anyone in our
day will write the story of Catherine
with such thoughtful penetration,such
dramatic intensity, or with such a
clear appreciation of the tangled and
international
bitter
background
against which she lived her life.
Catherine de'Medici was raised as
a symbol, married for political expediency into the most brilliant house
in Europe, and honored only for the
children whom, after ten years of
sterility, she bore to Henri II. In all,
she bore him ten, three of them to
become kings of France, and in the
years of her fertility she lived within
her family, removed from the political turmoil of the Renaissance struggle for power. Then, at the age of
forty, she put aside her distaff and set
out to become the ruler of France.

the Renaissance, his understanding
of true motives, his knowledge of the
conflicting forces underlying the delicate finesse of the sixteenth-century
diplomacy, enable him to write with
contemporary ease and fluency about
the living men and living issues of
400 years ago.

The many desirable constructional features of
the modern high-speed electric locomotive will
be incorporated in the design as a result of
General Electric's many years of experience in
building and equipping electric locomotives.

1.11111111
,

BY A NOSE
A century ago there was a race between a horse
and a locomotive. No such race will be necessary to determine the supremacy of the steam.
electric locomotive being built for the Union
Pacific Railroad by the General Electric Company. This new unit will get its first trial run
on the test tracks at the Erie, Pa. Works early
this year.
This new passenger unit will carry a steamturbine electric generating plant to feed power
to the traction motors. The turbine will exhaust through condensers, using the same water over and over with small additions to make
up for leakage. A new, highly efficient type of
steam boiler has been built, and heavy fuel
oil similar to that used in present-day locomotives will be used.
The new unit will be a double-cab locomotive,
streamlined, practically smokeless, and provided with power equipment for air-comb tioning the trailing passenger cars. It is rated at
5000 horsepower and is capable of hauling
1000-ton trains at a speed of 110 miles an hour.
The efficient fuel consumption will allow runs of
hundreds of miles at top speed without a stop.

LOSE A NEEDLE?
Not a needle in a haystack, but perhaps a needle
in a rug. During the manufacture of rugs,
needles may become broken and embedded in
the finished product. Former methods of inspection were tedious and time-wasting, but a
new magnetic device indicates the exact location of the steel fragment.
This iron detector, developed in the General
Engineering Laboratory of the General Electric
Company, consists of a test coil, a motor-generator set, and an amplifier. The rug is passed
through the magnetic field twice in directions
at right angles. The presence of a broken
needle causes a distortion in the magnetic field
and consequently an unbalanced voltage in the
secondary coil. This unbalance is amplified,
and the relays cause signal lights to glow.
Detectors of similar principle have previously
been developed for such uses as detecting scrap
iron in sugar cane and in scrap cellophane. The
General Engineering Laboratory is constantly
receiving problems from industrial concerns
and is developing equipment or giving suggestions to solve these problems.

Fencers Prepare

Anyone desiring to obtain boxing
instruction in preparation for the
tourney may do so by reporting every
Friday at the gym.

Jay Yee Quintet Drills
For Contest With Loyola
The members of the Jay Vee basketball squad will start drills this
week in preparation for a clash with
the Loyola Jay Vee group at Evergreen Saturday night. The contest
will be scheduled to take place before the varsity game.
In their rather short program this
campaign, the yearlings have done
very well. Except for a defeat in the
last minutes of play by Western
Maryland, the Jays have won all their
games. In two seasons of play they
have succumbed only once.

Coach Bob Owings has sounded the
call for all candidates aspiring for
positions on the baseball team. The
announcement comes rather early
this year, but as evidenced in various
other sports, an early start is absolutely essential. All new and veteran are to report at Latrobe 120 on

outfields.
